Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Light-Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) System for Civil Infrastructure Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award funds the acquisition of an advanced time-of-flight terrestrial Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) system to expand research opportunities, and to integrate cutting edge technology into the engineering and sciences classrooms at Lafayette College. Time-of-flight LIDAR uses laser pulses to capture the position and reflectivity of objects and surfaces in three-dimensional space. The new generation of LIDAR technology and associated post-processing software are far more capable and user friendly than previous generations. This particular LIDAR system is sturdy enough for hands-on use by undergraduate students and is equipped with full waveform processing to explore entirely new ways of visualizing and characterizing objects and terrain. The movement of LIDAR technology toward the mainstream is creating a revolution in how engineers and scientists sense, map, and record the natural and built environment. This revolution extends beyond the sciences and into fields of historical preservation, law enforcement, and art. In the foreseeable future, even personal vehicles will utilize LIDAR for autonomous navigation. Therefore, it is essential to introduce students at an undergraduate level to LIDAR, and assist them in identifying new and creative uses of this technology. The LIDAR system and the research it will enable will be used for: the training of future engineers and scientists through research and pedagogy that embraces new technology; the development of new collaborations and partnerships between academia and industry; and the significant enhancement of the capability to perform leading edge research at Lafayette College. Lafayette students involved in undergraduate research are typically inspired to pursue advanced degrees and research-related professions in both academia and industry. LIDAR is a versatile tool that will not only expand the research infrastructure at Lafayette but also provide new experimental experiences in the engineering and science curricula. The LIDAR system will support at least nine courses at Lafayette College as well as research intensive independent study and honors thesis courses, with approximately 400 student contacts per year. The high tech nature and portability of the LIDAR lends itself well to conducting outreach demonstrations for local high school students, many of whom are underrepresented minorities, to generate excitement about the STEM fields. The PI and Co-PIs have strong records mentoring women students and will take advantage of new efforts that are underway at Lafayette to recruit additional members of underrepresented groups into their research program

The intellectual merit of this project is centered on creating new knowledge and enhancing the research opportunities for faculty and undergraduate students at Lafayette College. The LIDAR system will have the immediate impact of enabling the PI, Co-PIs, research students, and outside collaborators in academia and industry to conduct research in the following areas: 1) transportation infrastructure, 2) slope stability and erosional processes, 3) hydrology and sediment transport, and 4) application of remote sensing to soil characterization. The projects in these areas directly address important issues and questions related to the built and natural environments at a local and national level. Specifically, the LIDAR system will enable research activities with the following impacts: development of best practices for using LIDAR to measure performance of Geosynthetic-Reinforced Soil Integrated Bridge Systems (GRS-IBS); movement toward consensus on how to efficiently design Column-Supported Embankments (CSEs); advancement in understanding of the complex soil-structure interaction that exists in slopes stabilized with slender reinforcing elements; characterization of the factors leading to instability of slopes near Lafayette College formed in the Franklin Formation; examination of the effects of bedrock geology and long-term dam operation on channel morphology along rivers and streams; and development of an innovative concept to characterize key properties of compacted soil by leveraging data from remote sensing instruments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Riegl VZ-400 terrestrial lidar system, purchased in 2014 through the National Science Foundation’s Major Research Instrumentation Program (Award 1428322), has had a profound positive impact on research and teaching activities at Lafayette College. As an Assistant Professor building a research program, I have been able to use the lidar system to pursue projects that address a critical need for smarter management our Nation’s infrastructure while simultaneously exposing my students to state of the art technology that prepares them for graduate school and the workplace of the future. The lidar has also enabled many collaborations among students and faculty across Lafayette College, even extending to non-STEM fields such as World Languages and Art.

 

 The research outcomes from this award stem from two projects that apply lidar to quantitatively assess the condition of earth retaining structures (i.e. retaining walls) and the slopes of earthen embankment dams. There are thousands of retaining walls and embankment dams across the U.S. and limited physical and financial resources for inspection of these structures over their lifetime. As we face a crisis of aging infrastructure, there is an increased understanding among owners and regulators that proactive asset management can increase system reliability and reduce long-term costs. Therefore, there is a need to evaluate existing inspection procedures and, where appropriate, introduce new methods that leverage the capabilities of lidar and other remote sensing technologies.

 

 Dams that are regulated by state or federal agencies are routinely inspected; however, it is conventional practice to rely on visual inspections of the riprap used to protect the slopes of a dam against erosion.  This approach is fairly subjective and reliant on the familiarity the inspector has with the site. My students and I have developed a method uses high-resolution 3D survey measurements obtained by remote sensing to quantify the roughness (i.e., microtopography) of the slope on a local scale. This enables anomalous areas to be easily identified using objective criteria.  Ultimately, we intend to provide operators of dams and levees the ability to best use their limited human resources for inspection and enable better targeting of areas that require maintenance.

 

Unlike dams, it is currently uncommon for walls to be periodically inspected after construction unless the wall is overseen by an agency that implements an asset management plan (e.g. National Park Service). While the proactive inspection of walls is presently rare, federal transportation funding through the Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st Century (MAP 21) bill encourages state DOTs to institute risk-based asset management systems for walls, so there is a need for efficient and effective inspection procedures. My students and I have developed a method that uses remote sensing data from lidar to evaluate the alignment of earth retaining structures and bridge abutments. Knowing the wall alignment is important for determining if the wall was built correctly and/or if the wall has moved laterally or settled over time.

 

The research outcomes described above have been disseminated through numerous conference papers, posters, and presentations. My students and I have also developed good relationships with several engineers, contractors, and regulators. These relationships have been valuable for exchanging information, accessing field sites, and making refinements to our approaches to maximize their practical utility. In addition to technical publications, we have written software that automates much of the data processing workflow we developed.

 

The broader impacts of this project include impacts on teaching, the creation of opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration, and community outreach. To date, over 50 undergraduate students at Lafayette College have directly worked with the lidar and/or data created by the lidar. Of these students, twelve students have worked on research that utilizes lidar. Six of the students are female. Through these efforts, the students have each gained extensive experience with the lidar equipment and associated data post-processing software. Three students who have worked on this project (one female) are enrolled in top graduate schools for geotechnical engineering (Virginia Tech and U. Texas Austin). In 2017, one student was awarded a Goldwater Scholarship in part for his work on the condition assessment of dam slopes. Outside of engineering, the lidar has been a central part of multiple interdisciplinary collaborations including digital preservation of German American heritage sites in Pennsylvania and determining environmental features that contribute to the breeding success of birds. We have also introduced members of the local community in the Lehigh Valley to lidar, including members of Easton City government and law enforcement.

 

The overall impacts of the lidar on research, teaching, and outreach are significant and ongoing. I am very grateful for the support of the National Science Foundation to be able to purchase the lidar system.
